fields.value: Investment-Specific Technology Growth:  Concepts and Recent Estimates

authorAffiliation.value: Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis

dsDescriptionValue.value: The strength of United States productivity growth in recent  years has been attributed to technological improvements that are, in  some sense, embodied in new types of capital equipment. However,  traditional growth theory and growth accounting techniques -- which  emphasize the role of disembodied, neutral technological progress --  are deficient in explaining this phenomenon. In this article, the  author outlines a model of investment-specific technological change  that has become popular for describing the notion of capital-embodied  growth and summarizes some recent estimates of the importance of this  type of technological progress for assessing United States productivity trends.
